semantic_identifier: 5441619 - Wisp & Willow Florals - sales_call - Discussion with Oscar Fuentes

hierarchy.meeting_title: 5441619 - Wisp & Willow Florals - sales_call - Discussion with Oscar Fuentes

sections.text: Megan Foster: Hi Oscar, good to see you again. Last time you mentioned you’re getting a lot of “something’s broken” messages coming in from Zendesk and Intercom, and then your team has to translate that into Jira tickets—often with duplicates and unclear impact. Today I’d love to focus on how Issue_Tracker can help you get to a clear “what do we fix next” list that both Support and Engineering trust. Does that still match what’s most urgent?
Oscar Fuentes: Yeah, that’s still the pain. We’re spending too much time figuring out if an issue is real, how many customers it’s hitting, and whether it’s actually hurting revenue. It’s noisy.

Megan Foster: Perfect. Let’s zoom in on one capability: issue_prioritization. The core idea is Issue_Tracker clusters similar customer-reported issues across your channels, then ranks those clusters with an explainable score—so you can see, “This is high because it’s spiking in volume, tagged severe, hitting high-ARR customers, and it’s tied to churn risk or a late-stage deal.” Where are you prioritizing today—Support SLA, Product impact/effort, or Sales deal blockers?

Oscar Fuentes: Honestly, it’s a mix and that’s part of the problem. Support escalates what’s loud. Product tries to be rational. And Sales only jumps in when a deal is at risk. There’s no shared logic.

Megan Foster: That’s exactly the gap Issue_Tracker is meant to close. It doesn’t replace Zendesk or Jira—it sits between them and standardizes the “issue object”: the theme or root cause, evidence from real conversations, and the list of impacted customers. Then prioritization gives each team a view that matches how they work: Support can see SLA-risk clusters, Engineering can see trend velocity and representative examples, and leadership can see revenue exposure.
Oscar Fuentes: The “evidence” part is interesting. Engineering always asks, “Is this one customer, or is it widespread?” And then someone has to go hunting across tickets.

Megan Foster: Exactly. For engineering managers, one of the most used workflows is opening a cluster and seeing: top examples, platform or channel breakdown, trend line over time, and which customers are affected. So before someone gets paged or you spin up an on-call fix, they can validate whether it’s actually widespread and getting worse.

Oscar Fuentes: That would help. But I’m a little worried about clustering accuracy. If the system merges different issues because customers describe them similarly, or splits one issue into five clusters because the language varies, we’ll lose trust fast.

Megan Foster: Totally fair—and it’s the right concern to raise on call two. Two things we do to protect trust. First, the priority score is explainable even if clustering needs tuning—you can see why something is ranking high and inspect the evidence. Second, we build in a “cluster hygiene” workflow: your team can quickly merge or split clusters, and Issue_Tracker learns from that feedback. In practice, we typically start with your top few categories—like checkout errors, delivery scheduling, or account access—so we tune where it matters most.
Oscar Fuentes: Okay. How much effort is that tuning? I don’t have someone who can babysit this daily.

Megan Foster: You shouldn’t need to. In week one, we do a short calibration pass—usually 60–90 minutes with someone from Support Ops or Product Ops—to review the top clusters and correct the obvious merges/splits. After that, it’s light-touch: your team only adjusts when they notice something off, and those adjustments reduce future errors. The goal is “good enough to drive decisions,” not perfection.
Oscar Fuentes: Makes sense. You also mentioned weighting by customer tier and revenue exposure. We’re on HubSpot for CRM. Can you pull in deal stage and customer value?

Megan Foster: Yes. Issue_Tracker integrates with your CRM so we can weight clusters by ARR tier, segment, and deal stage. So if an issue is impacting, say, your highest-value wholesale floral accounts—or it’s showing up in conversations tied to late-stage opportunities—it gets boosted. That’s where the prioritization becomes more than “most frequent”; it becomes “most important to the business.”
Oscar Fuentes: That’s compelling. We’ve had situations where a lower-volume bug affected a couple of big accounts, and it was more damaging than a noisy but minor issue.

Megan Foster: Exactly. Frequency alone misses that. The score can incorporate severity tags, velocity, tier/ARR, and churn risk flags—so you can configure it to match how Wisp & Willow thinks about impact. And each team can use the view they care about without arguing about whose list is “right.”
Oscar Fuentes: What does this look like day-to-day? Like, does my support lead log in and triage clusters instead of tickets?

Megan Foster: They can keep working tickets as normal. Issue_Tracker runs in parallel as the “intelligence layer.” Your support lead might start the day with a cluster view: “What’s rising fast? What’s severe? What’s hitting premium customers?” Then, when they escalate, they escalate the cluster—complete with evidence and impacted accounts—rather than forwarding five separate tickets and a Slack summary.
Oscar Fuentes: And then Engineering links that to Jira work?

Megan Foster: Exactly. The cluster stays linked to the downstream Jira issue or epic, and it stays linked back to the original Zendesk/Intercom conversations. That means you have a defensible history of decisions: when it was identified, why it was prioritized, what work was done, and current status. That’s huge for internal alignment and for customer follow-up.
Oscar Fuentes: That history would be useful. We’ve had debates like “did we decide not to fix this?” and nobody can find the rationale.

Megan Foster: Right. And since this is your second call, I want to connect it to the business outcome you mentioned last time—reducing fire drills and preventing revenue surprises. With issue_prioritization, you can build an Exec view that answers, “What issues are exposing revenue right now?” and a Sales view for deal blockers. But we can keep scope tight for rollout: Support + Engineering first.
Oscar Fuentes: Good. I’d rather start small and prove it.

Megan Foster: Great. Let me sanity-check your top use case. You said Engineering wants to validate if a bug is real and widespread before committing an on-call fix. If we set this up, your engineering manager can open a cluster and immediately see representative examples, platform breakdown, and velocity—so they know if it’s escalating. Does that match how you’d measure success in the first month?
Oscar Fuentes: Yes. If we can cut down the “is this real?” cycle and stop creating duplicate Jira tickets, that’s a win.

Megan Foster: Perfect. The other success metric I’d suggest is agreement: Support and Engineering align on the top 5 issues without a 30-minute debate. Because the ranking is explainable—“this is high because it’s severe, rising fast, and impacting high-tier customers”—it reduces the “loudest voice wins” problem.
Oscar Fuentes: I like that. One more concern: if the clustering is off early, engineers might dismiss it and go back to gut feel.

Megan Foster: Totally. To prevent that, we’ll do two things in the pilot. First, we’ll focus on a narrow slice—your top 2–3 categories—so accuracy is high where you’re looking most. Second, we’ll create a simple feedback loop: when Engineering says “this cluster is mixed,” we split it and mark the patterns. You’ll see the quality improve quickly, and we’ll review the before/after together at the end of week two.
Oscar Fuentes: Okay. So what are you proposing as next steps? Pilot?

Megan Foster: Yes. A 30-day pilot with Issue_Tracker focused on Zendesk/Intercom ingestion and Jira linking, plus issue_prioritization configured around your tiers and segments. Week 1 is setup and calibration. Weeks 2–4 are real usage with a weekly 20-minute check-in. At the end, we’ll evaluate on: reduction in duplicate Jira issues, time-to-validate for Engineering, and whether your top issues reflect revenue impact.
Oscar Fuentes: That sounds reasonable. What would you need from us to get started?

Megan Foster: Two things: access for the integrations—read access to Zendesk/Intercom and Jira, and CRM access for customer tier/ARR fields—and one point person for calibration, maybe your support operations lead. Also, I’d like you involved for 30 minutes in the first week to confirm your weighting inputs: what counts as “severe,” how you define tiers, and which segments matter most.
Oscar Fuentes: I can do that. Support Ops is Jenna—she can be the point person. And I can get you the integration approvals.

Megan Foster: Great. If you’re aligned, I’ll send a pilot plan today with the exact scope and success metrics, plus a simple agreement for the 30 days. Then we can schedule the kickoff early next week. If the pilot hits those metrics, we roll into the full subscription—sound good?
Oscar Fuentes: Yes, that works. Send it over, and let’s target a kickoff on Tuesday if possible.

Megan Foster: Tuesday works. I’ll email the pilot plan and a couple of time options in the next hour. Thanks, Oscar—this feels like a strong fit for how you’re trying to reduce noise and make prioritization more business-grounded.
Oscar Fuentes: Thanks, Megan. Looking forward to seeing it in action.
